Each question carries equal weight. You are advised to initially spend no more than 45 minutes on each question and then to return to any incomplete questions if you have time at the end. An indication of the number of marks allocated to parts of questions is shown in square brackets. No calculator is permitted in this examination. Page 1 Turn over No Calculator Section A 1. (a) Given vectors a = (1, 2, 3), b = (−3, 0, 1) and c = (1, 2, 2), compute the following: (i) 5a − c; (ii) (a · c)a; (iii) (a × b) + c; (iv) the non-reflex angle between a and b. [9] (b) Suppose that a = (1, 2, 3) is a vector. Determine the scalar equation of the plane Π perpendicular to a containing the point P = (2, 1, −2). [3] (c) Which of the following statements are true and which are false? For any statements that are false, provide a brief explanation as to why this is the case. (i) Given any complex number z ∈ C, Re(z) = Re(¯z). (ii) Given any complex number z ∈ C, z¯z is an integer. (iii) Given any complex number z ∈ C, the principal value Arg(z) of arg(z) satisfies Arg(z) ∈ [0, 2π]. [3] (d) Give an example of a system of two real simultaneous linear equations in two variables that has no solutions. (You do not need to justify your answer.) [2] (e) Using the augmented matrix and row operations, find the solution set of the following system of real simultaneous linear equations: x + 3y + 2z = 1, 5y + 3z = −3, 3x + 4y + 3z = 6. [4] (c) Let V = Mnn(R) be the vector space of n × n matrices. Prove or disprove that the set W = {A ∈ Mnn(R) : A = A2} is a subspace of V . [4] (d) Let V = R3 and U be a subspace of V defined by U = {(x, y, z) ∈ R3 : 2x − 3y + z = 0}. Determine a basis for U . [4] (e) Prove or disprove whether the following mappings are linear: (i) T : R3 → R2 defined by T ((x, y, z)) = (x, x + y), (ii) T : R2 → R2 defined by T ((x, y)) = (y2, x2). (i) Calculate z6 in both modulus-argument form and exponential form, giving the princi- pal value of the argument. (ii) What is the smallest choice of n ∈ N so that zn ∈ N? (iii) Find all the fourth roots of z. Present your answers in exponential form giving the principal value of the argument. [9] (b) Suppose that A =     1 1 5 2 2 3 0 0 1     . Use the Gaussian Elimination Algorithm to determine whether A is invertible or not. In particular, if A is invertible then determine A−1. [7] (c) Suppose that A, B and C are matrices so that (1) A · B is defined and is a 5 × 3 matrix; (2) C · A is defined and is a 3 × 3 matrix. Determine the dimensions of each of the matrices A, B and C. Justify your answer. [5] (d) Suppose that A = ( a b c d ) is a 2 × 2 matrix such that a, b, c, d are positive real numbers. [4] (b) Let U and W be subspaces of a vector space V . (i) Prove that U ∩W is a subspace of V . (ii) Prove that U +W is a subspace of V where U +W = {u + w : u ∈ U and w ∈ W }. [4] (c) Let P2 be the vector space of real polynomials of order 2 defined by P2 = {a0 + a1x + a2x2 : a0, a1, a2 ∈ R}. What are the coordinates of v ∈ P2 given by v = x2 + 4x − 3 with respect to the ordered basis {e1, e2, e3} given by e1 = x2 − 2x + 5, e2 = 2x2 − 3x, e3 = x + 3. [4] (d) Consider the vector space of 2 × 2 real matrices V = M22(R). (i) What is the dimension of V ? Write down the standard basis for V . (ii) Consider the linear transformation T : V → V defined by T (A) = M · A where M =( 1 −1 −2 2 ) . Find a basis and dimension of the kernel of T and a basis and dimen- sion of the image of T . [8] (e) This question involves the rotation transform given by x = ˜x cos(α) − ˜y sin(α) and y = ˜x sin(α) + ˜y cos(α) where the value of the rotation angle α is chosen to eliminate the cross term xy. Deter- mine an expression for −2x2 + 2 √ 3xy − 4 = 0 in ( ˜x, ˜y) coordinates and hence identify the type and eccentricity of this conic section.
